title: Spokane medical assistant accused of drugging, prostituting victim
summary:
The Washington Department of Health says it has suspended the license of a Spokane-area medical assistant who is accused of injecting a victim with heroin and forcing that person into prostitution.
Heather Kemper faces one count of promoting prostitution, a felony, in Spokane County Superior Court, the Department of Health said in an announcement Monday.
Online court records show the charge was filed Jan. 10 and Kemper was released from jail in late February.
The department did not disclose the age or gender of the victim, or say whether the victim was a patient of Kemper’s.
Kemper may not practice as a medical assistant in Washington until the charge is resolved.

title: Up to 8 inches of snow expected to fall on Spokane starting Friday
summary:

title: Washington’s highest court gets chief justice from Spokane, first Native American member

title: Washington campgrounds to close Monday in effort to stop coronavirus spread

title: Washington unemployment rate for October was 4.5 percent
summary:
Associated PressOLYMPIA – Washington state’s October unemployment rate dipped slightly to 4.5 percent from the previous month.
According to numbers released Wednesday by the state Employment Security Department, October’s rate was down from September’s rate of 4.6 percent.
Job gains and losses are estimates based on a survey by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The unemployment rate counts the percentage of people who are unemployed and actively looking for work, and doesn’t include those who have stopped looking for work.
The national unemployment rate for October was 3.6 percent, and the rate in the Seattle-Bellevue-Everett region was 3 percent.

summary:

title: Spokane County unemployment rate increased to 5.6% in January
summary:
Spokane County’s unemployment rate increased to 5.6% in January, according to the Washington state Employment Security Department.
The county shed 4,500 nonfarm and 4,600 private sector jobs in January, compared to a month prior, according to the department.
The construction sector dropped 700 jobs, retail trade lost 1,300 jobs, and the state government sector gained 500 jobs in January.

title: Spokane police officer booked into jail on rape charge
summary:
Spokane police officer Nathan Nash, who has been under investigation for a reported sexual assault since late October, was arrested late Friday afternoon and booked into the Spokane County Jail on a rape charge.
Spokane County Sheriff’s detectives began investigating Nash, 36, after the victim’s father reported the sexual assault on Oct. 23.
Nash, a patrol officer, was conducting a follow-up interview with the victim of a domestic dispute when the woman said he sexually assaulted her.
Nash denied assaulting the victim on Nov. 1 via a statement from his lawyer, Rocky Treppiedi, a former assistant city attorney.
He was booked into the Spokane County Jail just after 5 p.m. Friday on one charge of second-degree rape and two counts of official misconduct.

title: City Council raises property taxes by 1%
summary:
The Spokane City Council approved a 1% property tax increase on Monday.
Monday’s action comes as the City Council continues to consider Mayor David Condon’s proposed $1.1 billion city budget for 2020, about $205 million of which is funded directly by city taxpayers.
City CFO Gavin Cooley noted that the property tax increase is less than half the rate of inflation.
Condon’s budget proposal, formally introduced to the council earlier this month, will be inherited and implemented by his successor Nadine Woodward.
The measure authorized the city to collect 30 cents per $1,000 of assessed property valuation every year, which in 2020 will total an estimated $6.35 million.

title: Then and Now: Spokane Convention Center

The former Washington State Pavilion theater, now the First Interstate Center for the Arts, and the original Spokane Convention Center building are a legacy of the fair, planting a seed of future economic development.
The original convention center from Expo was significantly expanded in 1989 with construction of the Washington State International Agricultural Trade Center facing the river.
In 1989, with the approval of the Legislature, the Spokane Public Facilities District was formed to shepherd the replacement of the 1954 Spokane Coliseum.
The PFD officially took over the operation of the First Interstate Center for the Arts and convention center from the city in 2003.

Job gains and losses are estimates based on a survey by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The unemployment rate counts the percentage of people who are unemployed and actively looking for work, and doesn’t include those who have stopped looking for work.
The national unemployment rate for October was 3.6 percent, and the rate in the Seattle-Bellevue-Everett region was 3 percent.

title: Spokane judge becomes second to block Trump administration’s ‘conscience rule’
summary:
OLYMPIA – A federal judge in Spokane became the second in two days to block the Trump administration’s new expanded “conscience rule” that would allow health care workers to refuse care for religious or moral reasons.
U.S. District Judge Stanley Bastian granted state attorneys a summary judgment in a lawsuit that argued the rule would hurt access to reproductive health care, end-of-life care decisions and care for transgender patients.
The state had sued the U.S. Health and Human Services Department, which announced the rule in May; it was scheduled to begin later this month.
Federal health care funding could be cut off if federal officials believed the state violated the rule.
On Wednesday, a federal judge in New York ruled in a similar case challenging the rule brought by 19 states, the District of Columbia and several large cities.

The crop is estimated at 138.2 million 40-pound boxes, up from the 137.3 million box estimate in August, according to the association’s Nov. 1 apple storage report.
But this year’s crop is below the record 141.8 million crop size from 2014.
The statewide harvest was mostly completed, according to the report, but harvest of a few additional orchards could boost the overall crop size.
As expected, Gala was the top variety, making up 23.5% of the overall Washington crop.

The only building was a 15-by-22-foot carpentry shop, which Cataldo turned into Spokane’s first Roman Catholic Church for white settlers with the addition of a simple cross on the roof.
In 1888, a school building of two and a half stories was constructed next to the church and operated by the Sisters of the Holy Names.
The first brick church was torn down and the school building was used as a convent for decades before falling into disuse.
The Sicilian priest who had spent a lifetime of spreading the Catholic faith and tradition through the region died in Pendleton, Oregon, in 1928 at age 92.

title: Confusing affirmative action initiative a product of long back-and-forth about best way to afford opportunity

People who oppose changes to the state’s restrictions on affirmative action programs and signed Referendum 88 would vote “Rejected,” even though the measure was put on the ballot by a group opposed to those changes.

title: Spokane County unemployment rate increases to 4.9% in November
summary:
Spokane County’s unemployment rate increased slightly to 4.9% in November, according to nonseasonally adjusted data from the Washington State Employment Security Department.
The county dropped 1,200 nonfarm jobs and 1,200 private-sector positions in November, compared with October, according to the department.
The retail trade sector added 800 jobs, and the trade, transportation and utilities sector posted 900 jobs gained.
The county’s unemployment rate was 4.8% in October and 4.8% in November 2018.
The state’s seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 4.4% in November.

title: Spokane on track to receive about half of normal snowfall for December
summary:

title: Spokane County approves $675 million budget
summary:
Spokane County commissioners approved a $675 million budget Monday, which is smaller than last year due to a change in behavioral health funding.
Spokane County CFO Tonya Wallace said the county also paid off $13 million of wastewater debt that was in last year’s $790 million budget, and is not in this year’s.
Last month, commissioners voted to increase the county’s 2020 general levy, its conservation futures levy and the road levy by 1%.
About $3 million of the banked capacity will be used for road projects and $2.7 million will be used for county campus projects, said Wallace.
County Commissioner Al French said the county can use taxes collected through the road fund for one-time improvements.

title: 2 inches of snow falls on Spokane and chaos ensues on Walnut Street
summary:

title: Spokane man dies in crash near Mead on Saturday night
summary:

Heck is serving his fourth term representing Washington’s 10th District, southwest of Seattle.
Heck, 67, serves on the House Intelligence Committee, which has played a key role in the impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump.

title: Pacific Northwest seeing stormy end to 2019
summary:
SEATTLE – The Pacific Northwest will ring in the new year with a stormy weather pattern that is expected to bring rounds of heavy rain, gusty winds and snow to the mountains.
Washington Department of Transportation officials temporarily closed the Hood Canal Bridge Tuesday morning because of wind gusts from 40 to 50 mph.
Kitsap Transit officials in Bremerton said fast ferry sailings could be canceled in the afternoon because of high winds.
In Oregon, gale warnings and high surf advisories were in effect Tuesday with up to 3 inches of rain expected in places.
In the Cascade Mountains in southern Washington and in Oregon total snow accumulations of 8 to 15 inches were expected with gusty winds.

title: Spokane County unemployment rate increased to 5.6% in January
summary:
Spokane County’s unemployment rate increased to 5.6% in January, according to the Washington state Employment Security Department.
The county shed 4,500 nonfarm and 4,600 private sector jobs in January, compared to a month prior, according to the department.
The construction sector dropped 700 jobs, retail trade lost 1,300 jobs, and the state government sector gained 500 jobs in January.
The county’s unemployment rate was in 4.8% December and 6.8% in December 2018.

title: Christmas tree lights up Riverfront Park
summary:
By Lisa Leinberger For The Spokesman-ReviewAs a growing crowd waited for the 3,000 feet of Christmas lights to shine on Spokane’s Christmas tree, revelers sipped hot chocolate and negotiated the best spots next to portable heaters.
There was a visit from Santa as well as Disney princesses, and some danced to Christmas tunes to keep warm.
The tree, which has been part of Spokane’s holiday celebrations for many years, sported 2,500 lights and a 10-foot bow.
The Spokane Symphony Chorale led the crowd in Christmas carols and a handful of Christmas dad jokes before David Condon took the stage to light the tree for the last time as Spokane mayor.
The tree lit up in spectacular blue, green and white lights, officially kicking off the holiday season in Spokane, and the mayor wished everyone a Merry Christmas and happy holidays.

title: Spokane International Airport breaks record for passengers in 2019
summary:
Spokane International Airport set a new record for passenger activity in 2019, exceeding more than 4 million travelers for the first time in its history.
It’s the third consecutive year of record-breaking passenger traffic at the airport, which reported a 2.9% increase in passengers flying in and out of Spokane compared with 2018.
“As the Spokane/Coeur d’Alene region’s economy continues to advance, so does the demand for connectivity to current as well as new destinations,” Ezra Eckhardt, chair of the Spokane Airport Board, said in a statement.
The airport’s busiest month in 2019 was July, with more than 398,300 travelers passing through its gates.
The largest increase in year-over-year passengers occurred in December with more than 366,300 passengers, marking a 5.4% increase in passengers over December 2018.

title: T-Mobile rolls out 5G service in Spokane area this week
summary:
T-Mobile is rolling out its fifth-generation wireless network nationwide this week, but Spokane customers shouldn’t expect to see blazing fast speeds just yet.
Although T-Mobile is expanding 5G to 5,000 cities nationwide, including Spokane and Spokane Valley, the new wireless service is a 600 MHz, low-band spectrum that is the foundation for ultra-fast speeds in the future.

title: Oregon man killed in I-90 crash
summary:

title: Spokane International Airport anticipates increase in passengers for holiday season
summary:
Passenger traffic at Spokane International has gradually increased every year since 2013, with a record of nearly 4 million passengers traveling through the facility last year.
Spokane International Airport is anticipating an increase in passengers this holiday season, mirroring a nationwide projection that air travel will increase 3% compared to last year.
Airport officials are expecting about 12,000 passengers per day to fly in and out of Spokane International from Dec. 19 to Jan. 2.
